repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Fixes #3805.

This adds support for "class" level docs when a enum is declared with `cpdef` and the docs should show up under `__doc__` in python. It also supports writing docs for `cdef enum` (and enum from `cpp` I believe) in the same style, but the docs won't be stored anywhere in that case.

The only issue currently is that the enum code is generated from `CpdefEnums.pyx`. What this means is that we manually handle dumping the docstring to the generated code. However, I'm not sure how to handle quote mixing. I.e. I just put triple-quotes around the text, but this would break if the original text e.g. was quoted with triple-single-quotes and has a triple-quote in the text itself. There's probably some standard way of escaping such generic text, but I'm not sure what it is.

Also, I wasn't familiar with cython internal before this, so I may be way of with the changes!?

comment_data.body:
The string constant would need to be an `StringEncoding.EncodedString()`, but rather, I think we should inherit the docstring from the superclass here and not set a default.
```suggestion
        self.doc = doc
```
I understand that this makes the test a little more difficult, but I'd rather not make a test rely on the docstring of Python's `IntEnum` class at all, so I'm fine with a test that the docstrings set for other enum classes do not leak into the enums that have no docstring, and not testing for a specific string value.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4147,8 +4148,12 @@ class CEnumType(CIntLike, CType):
     signed = 1
     rank = -1  # Ranks below any integer type
 
-    def __init__(self, name, cname, typedef_flag, namespace=None):
+    def __init__(self, name, cname, typedef_flag, namespace=None, doc=None):
         self.name = name
+        if doc is None:
+            self.doc = "An enumeration."
+        else:
+            self.doc = doc

@@ -4139,6 +4139,7 @@ def is_optional_template_param(type):
 
 class CEnumType(CIntLike, CType):
     #  name           string
+    #  doc            string or None which then defaults to "An enumeration."

comment_data.body:
Just to simplify the next change we make in this place:
```suggestion
                     "enum_doc": self.doc,
                     },
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4190,7 +4195,8 @@ def create_type_wrapper(self, env):
         env.use_utility_code(CythonUtilityCode.load(
             "EnumType", "CpdefEnums.pyx",
             context={"name": self.name,
-                     "items": tuple(self.values)},
+                     "items": tuple(self.values),
+                     "enum_doc": self.doc},

comment_data.body: I'm not sure I fully understood the second half of the paragraph. But I hadn't realized that the `"An enumeration."` originates from python's Enum - I couldn't figure out where it came from that's why I originally kept it. So yeah, it makes sense to me to keep the default `__doc__` to `None`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4147,8 +4148,12 @@ class CEnumType(CIntLike, CType):
     signed = 1
     rank = -1  # Ranks below any integer type
 
-    def __init__(self, name, cname, typedef_flag, namespace=None):
+    def __init__(self, name, cname, typedef_flag, namespace=None, doc=None):
         self.name = name
+        if doc is None:
+            self.doc = "An enumeration."
+        else:
+            self.doc = doc

comment_data.body: Right, I wasn't familiar with the `repr` specific before. I updated the other half of the `if` to also use `repr`.
Hmm I just noticed that my changes actually set the docstring to `None`, don't they? That wasn't intended.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4147,8 +4148,12 @@ class CEnumType(CIntLike, CType):
     signed = 1
     rank = -1  # Ranks below any integer type
 
-    def __init__(self, name, cname, typedef_flag, namespace=None):
+    def __init__(self, name, cname, typedef_flag, namespace=None, doc=None):
         self.name = name
+        if doc is None:
+            self.doc = "An enumeration."
+        else:
+            self.doc = doc

comment_data.body:
Are you sure this is supposed to work? I'm not very comfortable with jinja, but when I tried to compile this locally I got `EnumType:53:7: undeclared name not builtin: enum_doc`.

So I guess you do want the keep the inherited python docstring when it's not set in cython? So I'll just remove the test testing the value of the docstring when it's not specified. Since I'm assuming we can't rely on python's enum docstring to not change!?
Sorry, yes, you're totally right. Fixed my suggestion.

> So I'll just remove the test testing the value of the docstring when it's not specified. Since I'm assuming we can't rely on python's enum docstring to not change!?

Yes. That's what I meant in my earlier comment with not testing the superclass docstring value itself.
I removed the indentation because it didn't compile with it.
These need different names. Enums have global names in C.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -11,5 +11,19 @@ cpdef enum PxdEnum:
     RANK_1 = 37
     RANK_2 = 389
 
+cpdef enum cpdefPxdDocEnum:
+    """Home is where...
+    """
+    RANK_0 = 11
+
+cpdef enum cpdefPxdDocLineEnum:
+    """Home is where..."""
+    RANK_0 = 11

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

milestone.description:
Goals:
 New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
 Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
 Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
 Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Add doc support for cpdef enum
